Personalization Improves Privacy–Accuracy Tradeoffs
in Federated Learning

Alberto Bietti    Chen-Yu Wei    Miroslav Dudík    John Langford    Zhiwei Steven Wu
Abstract

Large-scale machine learning systems often involve data distributed across a collection of users. Federated learning algorithms leverage this structure by communicating model updates to a central server, rather than entire datasets. In this paper, we study stochastic optimization algorithms for a personalized federated learning setting involving local and global models subject to user-level (joint) differential privacy. While learning a private global model induces a cost of privacy, local learning is perfectly private. We provide generalization guarantees showing that coordinating local learning with private centralized learning yields a generically useful and improved tradeoff between accuracy and privacy. We illustrate our theoretical results with experiments on synthetic and real-world datasets.

Machine Learning, ICML

1 Introduction

Many modern applications of machine learning involve data from a large set of users. In such settings, both privacy considerations and bandwidth limits may require keeping each user’s data on their device, instead communicating with a centralized server via shared model updates, a scenario commonly known as federated learning (Kairouz et al., 2021). When the data distribution varies across users, it is often beneficial to consider personalized models where parts of the model (e.g., user-specific embeddings, or additive offsets) are local to each user, leading to updates that may be performed locally. Such personalized federated learning has been deployed at scale in a wide range of applications, including keyboard next-word prediction (Wang et al., 2019), automated speech recognition, and news personalization (Paulik et al., 2021).

In this paper, we focus on personalized federated learning algorithms based on stochastic optimization, which are the most widely used in this context (McMahan et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2021). Concretely, we consider stochastic optimization problems of the following form:

minw,θ1:N⁡{f​(w,θ1:N):=1N​∑i=1N𝔼ξ∼Pi⁡[fi​(w,θi,ξ)]},subscript𝑤subscript𝜃:1𝑁assign𝑓𝑤subscript𝜃:1𝑁1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝔼similar-to𝜉subscript𝑃𝑖subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤subscript𝜃𝑖𝜉\min_{w,{\theta_{1:N}}}\left\{f(w,{\theta_{1:N}}):=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}_{\xi\sim P_{i}}[f_{i}(w,\theta_{i},\xi)]\right\}, (1)

where N𝑁N is the number of users, w𝑤w a global parameter, θ1:N=(θ1,…,θN)subscript𝜃:1𝑁subscript𝜃1…subscript𝜃𝑁{\theta_{1:N}}=(\theta_{1},\ldots,\theta_{N}) a set of local parameters, and Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i} denotes the sample distribution for user i𝑖i. Similar objectives have been considered in other works (Agarwal et al., 2020; Hanzely et al., 2021). The personalization problem raises the question of how much learning should happen at the local vs global level: if the local models are expressive enough, local learning alone should suffice to learn good models with enough samples per user, yet if the data has some shared structure across users, a global model may help us learn more efficiently.

Although federated learning algorithms do not store user data in the central server, private user information may still be leaked in the resulting models, unless appropriate mechanisms are applied to guarantee privacy. In this work, we consider the notion of user-level (joint) differential privacy (DP) (Dwork et al., 2006, 2010a; Kearns et al., 2014), which ensures an adversary cannot reliably detect the presence or absence of all the data associated with a single user based on the output information. Such a notion has been used successfully in federated learning problems, with practical optimization algorithms that lead to useful privacy guarantees (McMahan et al., 2018; Hu et al., 2021).

Unfortunately, assuring such privacy may come at a cost to accuracy (see, for example, the lower bounds of Bassily et al., 2014). The key question we address is:

Can we leverage personalization to improve privacy–accuracy tradeoffs in federated learning?

The insight motivating our work is that in personalized federated learning, it is only the global portion of the optimization that needs to experience this drop in accuracy. A user’s local model can compensate for the privacy-guaranteeing accuracy limitations of the global model. We formalize this by considering algorithms with a personalization parameter α𝛼\alpha that may vary the level of personalization from local learning (α=0𝛼0\alpha=0) to global learning (α=∞𝛼\alpha=\infty). We then show generalization bounds on the objective 1 of the form

f​(wn,θ1:N,n)−f∗≤Cstat​(α,n,N)+Cpriv​(α,ϵ,N),𝑓subscript𝑤𝑛subscript𝜃:1𝑁𝑛superscript𝑓subscript𝐶stat𝛼𝑛𝑁subscript𝐶priv𝛼italic-ϵ𝑁f(w_{n},\theta_{1:N,n})-f^{*}\leq C_{\text{stat}}(\alpha,n,N)+C_{\text{priv}}(\alpha,\epsilon,N), (2)

where f∗=minw,θ1:N⁡f​(w,θ1:N)superscript𝑓subscript𝑤subscript𝜃:1𝑁𝑓𝑤subscript𝜃:1𝑁f^{*}=\min_{w,{\theta_{1:N}}}f(w,{\theta_{1:N}}) is the optimal risk, n𝑛n is the number of observed samples per user and ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is the DP privacy parameter. Here, we expect the second term to vanish when α→0→𝛼0\alpha\to 0, as local learning does not suffer from privacy. Crucially, this privacy cost does not depend on the number of samples per user n𝑛n, while the first term, which captures statistical efficiency, generally decreases with n𝑛n for any α𝛼\alpha. This emphasizes how adjusting the level of personalization through α𝛼\alpha can help improve generalization by adjusting the trade-off between these two terms.

Concretely, we provide precise guarantees of this form for simple federated private stochastic gradient algorithms, where the number of iterations corresponds to the number of samples per user n𝑛n, and the personalization parameter α𝛼\alpha is given by the relative step-size between global and local updates. In particular, we show that α𝛼\alpha affects the complexity of learning by changing the geometry of the optimization: in problems that benefit from global models, small α𝛼\alpha makes learning more difficult but reduces the cost of privacy. We complement our theoretical results with experiments on synthetic and real-world federated learning datasets, which illustrate how varying the step-size ratio leads to improved trade-offs between accuracy and privacy.

2 Related Work

Model personalizaton.

There are a variety of approaches for personalization in federated learning. In local fine-tuning, a global model is learnt by federated learning and then used as a warm start for on-device learning from the cache of local data (Wang et al., 2019; Paulik et al., 2021). This approach can be augmented with federated learning of hyperparameters (Wang et al., 2019; Jiang et al., 2019; Khodak et al., 2019) to obtain federated learning variants of meta-learning approaches like MAML (Finn et al., 2017) and Reptile (Nichol et al., 2018).

Another approach is to view personalization as a multi-task learning problem, and learn task-specific models with a regularization that forces parameters for similar tasks to be close, e.g., in a Euclidean norm (Vanhaesebrouck et al., 2017; Smith et al., 2017; Arivazhagan et al., 2019; Mansour et al., 2020; Dinh et al., 2020; Shen et al., 2020; Huang et al., 2021; Marfoq et al., 2021; Singhal et al., 2021). Task similarity is typically expressed as a weighted undirected graph, a matrix, or a clustering. A special case of the multi-task approach is to learn a global model in addition to local models, which are regularized to be close to the global model (Mansour et al., 2020; Deng et al., 2020; Hanzely & Richtárik, 2020; Hanzely et al., 2021; Marfoq et al., 2021). This is closest to the approach here, which also separates global and local parameters. However, the approach here is more general, because we allow a broader range of modeling relationships between the global and local parameters, similar to federated residual learning (Agarwal et al., 2020). The statistical aspects of such personalization models were studied by Mansour et al. (2020); Agarwal et al. (2020), who in particular provide generalization guarantees for additive personalization models similar to ours. However, compared to the present paper, these works do not provide privacy guarantees nor study the effect of varying the level of personalization.

Privacy.

The results here advance a recent line of work that provides formal user-level privacy guarantees for model personalizaton in federated learning. Similar to the prior work of Jain et al. (2021) and Hu et al. (2021), we adopt the privacy formulation of joint differential privacy (JDP, Kearns et al., 2014), a variation of DP that is more suitable for the problem of model personalization than standard DP. Jain et al. (2021) provides private algorithms that first learn a shared linear representation for all users, and allow each user to learn their local linear regression model over the lower-dimensional representation. This leads to a factorized model of personalization, which is different than ours and not handled by our theoretical assumptions due to non-convexity. Hu et al. (2021) provides a private personalizaton algorithm through the mean-regularized multi-task learning objective without establishing its statistical rates. In contrast, we consider more general personalization schemes and provide statistical guarantees.

The results here are also related to other work in DP with a similar motivation to model personalization. Li et al. (2020) studies meta-learning under DP. Their framework does not cover model personalization with a separate model for each user. Noble et al. (2021) studies federated learning with DP with heterogeneous data across nodes, but they do not support personalization. Bellet et al. (2018) studies fully decentralized DP algorithms for collaborative learning over a network instead of federated learning.

Finally, the notion of user-level privacy has also been adopted in prior works (McMahan et al., 2018; Levy et al., 2021), but these do not consider model personalization.

3 Preliminaries

In this section, we introduce the problem of personalized federated optimization, as well as the notion of user-level privacy that we consider.

3.1 Problem setting

We consider stochastic optimization problems of the form

minw,θ1:N⁡{f​(w,θ1:N):=1N​∑i=1Nfi​(w,θi)},subscript𝑤subscript𝜃:1𝑁assign𝑓𝑤subscript𝜃:1𝑁1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤subscript𝜃𝑖\min_{w,{\theta_{1:N}}}\left\{f(w,{\theta_{1:N}}):=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}f_{i}(w,\theta_{i})\right\},

where N𝑁N is the number of users, w∈ℝdw𝑤superscriptℝsubscript𝑑𝑤w\in{\mathbb{R}}^{{d_{w}}} a global parameter, θ1:N=(θ1,…,θN)∈(ℝdθ)Nsubscript𝜃:1𝑁subscript𝜃1…subscript𝜃𝑁superscriptsuperscriptℝsubscript𝑑𝜃𝑁{\theta_{1:N}}=(\theta_{1},\ldots,\theta_{N})\in({\mathbb{R}}^{{d_{\theta}}})^{N} a set of local parameters, and fi​(w,θi):=𝔼ξ∼Pi⁡[fi​(w,θi,ξ)]assignsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑤subscript𝜃𝑖subscript𝔼similar-to𝜉subscript𝑃𝑖subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤subscript𝜃𝑖𝜉f_{i}(w,\theta_{i}):=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}_{\xi\sim P_{i}}[f_{i}(w,\theta_{i},\xi)] is the expected risk of user i𝑖i, with random samples ξ𝜉\xi drawn from an unknown user-specific distribution Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i}.

While our algorithms may be run on arbitrary differentiable models, our analysis focuses on the convex setting, where fi​(w,θi,ξi)subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤subscript𝜃𝑖subscript𝜉𝑖f_{i}(w,\theta_{i},\xi_{i}) is jointly convex in (w,θi)𝑤subscript𝜃𝑖(w,\theta_{i}) for all ξisubscript𝜉𝑖\xi_{i}.

Additive model.

An important special case is the additive model for supervised learning, where dw=dθ=dsubscript𝑑𝑤subscript𝑑𝜃𝑑{d_{w}}={d_{\theta}}=d, and

fi​(w,θi,(x,y))=ℓ​(y,(w+θi)⊤​x),subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤subscript𝜃𝑖𝑥𝑦ℓ𝑦superscript𝑤subscript𝜃𝑖top𝑥f_{i}(w,\theta_{i},(x,y))=\ell(y,(w+\theta_{i})^{\top}x), (3)

where ℓℓ\ell is a loss function and ξ=(x,y)𝜉𝑥𝑦\xi=(x,y) is a training sample.

As a running example, consider a movie recommendation app, which seeks to predict how each user i𝑖i will rate any given movie. In this case, x𝑥x corresponds to the features describing a movie (e.g., its genre, popularity, length, actors, etc.), and y𝑦y is the user’s rating of that movie. Following the federated protocol, the data about user activity stays on the device and only model parameters can be communicated to the server. In this case, only the information about the global parameter w𝑤w is communicated.

The additive model makes the optimization problem (1) underdetermined, with many possible equivalent solutions obtained by adding any vector v∈ℝd𝑣superscriptℝ𝑑v\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d} to w𝑤w and then subtracting v𝑣v from each θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i}, effectively “shifting” the predictive ability between global and local parameters. This is what allows the optimization algorithm to achieve different tradeoffs between statistical generalization (accuracy) and sharing of information across users (privacy).

To develop the intuition about this tradeoff, first consider the homogeneous scenario, where the optimal parameters θi∗∈arg⁡minθ⁡𝔼(x,y)∼Pi⁡[ℓ​(y,θ⊤​x)]superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖subscript𝜃subscript𝔼similar-to𝑥𝑦subscript𝑃𝑖ℓ𝑦superscript𝜃top𝑥\theta_{i}^{*}\in\arg\min_{\theta}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}_{(x,y)\sim P_{i}}[\ell(y,\theta^{\top}x)] for each user are equal (θ1∗=⋯=θN∗superscriptsubscript𝜃1⋯superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑁\theta_{1}^{*}=\cdots=\theta_{N}^{*}). There are two extreme approaches: (i) local learning, where only θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i} are trained individually for each user, leading to poor sample complexity but perfect privacy (ii) global learning, where only w𝑤w is trained, and we benefit from using samples from all users, but need communication with a centralized server and lose privacy.

In the more realistic heterogeneous scenario, when the θi∗superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i}^{*} are different but have some shared components, e.g., only some coordinates differ across users, joint learning of w𝑤w and θ1:Nsubscript𝜃:1𝑁{\theta_{1:N}} can achieve greater accuracy (at the same number of samples) than both local and global learning, by leveraging more samples to estimate the shared components, while benefiting from user-specific data to personalize. Note that in this case, it is possible to further improve privacy, by allowing some shared components to be fitted entirely locally. Quantifying this improvement is the focus of our work.

In the movie recommendation example, if only global learning is performed, the prediction w⊤​xsuperscript𝑤top𝑥w^{\top}x can use overall popularity statistics, but the resulting prediction is the same for all users, without any personalization. On the other hand, if only local learning is performed, although the system can fully personalize and provide full privacy, the quality of recommendation is limited by the number of movies the user watched before. With joint learning, the system can capture both global trends through w𝑤w and adapt to each user’s preference through θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i}.

3.2 User-level (joint) differential privacy

We aim to provide user-level privacy (Dwork et al., 2010a), which ensures that an adverary cannot detect the presence or absence of all of the data associated with a single user when given the output of the algorithm. To achieve this goal, we design algorithms using the billboard model (Hsu et al., 2014) of differential privacy (DP) (Dwork et al., 2006). Let us first revisit the definition of DP, which informally requires that changing any single user’s data cannot change the algorithm’s output by much.

Definition 3.1 (User-level DP; Dwork et al., 2006, 2010a).

A randomized mechanism M𝑀M is (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-differential privacy (DP) if for all pairs of data sets D,D′𝐷superscript𝐷′D,D^{\prime} that differ by a single user’s data and all events E𝐸E in the output range,

Pr⁡[M​(D)∈E]≤eϵ​Pr⁡[M​(D′)∈E]+δ.Pr𝑀𝐷𝐸superscript𝑒italic-ϵPr𝑀superscript𝐷′𝐸𝛿\displaystyle\Pr[M(D)\in E]\leq e^{\epsilon}\Pr[M(D^{\prime})\in E]+\delta.

Billboard model.

In the billboard model, a server computes aggregate information subject to the constraint of DP and shares the information as public messages with all N𝑁N users. Then, based on the public messages and their own private data, each user computes their own personalized model. The billboard model is particularly compatible with algorithms in the federated setting, where the DP messages are typically noisy summary statistics about the users’ local models (Jain et al., 2021; Hu et al., 2021). Hsu et al. (2014) show that algorithms under the billboard model provide an extremely strong privacy guarantee, known as joint differential privacy (JDP, Kearns et al., 2014).

Joint differential privacy (JDP).

Let Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i} denote the collection of samples associated with each user i𝑖i. Two datasets D𝐷D and D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime} are called i𝑖i-neighbors if they only differ by user i𝑖i’s private data. For any mechanism M𝑀M, we denote M−i​(D)subscript𝑀𝑖𝐷M_{-i}(D) as the output information to all other users except user i𝑖i.

Definition 3.2 (Joint-Differential Privacy, JDP).

An algorithm M𝑀M is (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-jointly differentially private, written as (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-JDP, if for all i𝑖i, all i𝑖i-neighboring datasets D,D′𝐷superscript𝐷′D,D^{\prime}, and all events E𝐸E in the output space to all other users except i𝑖i,

Pr⁡[M−i​(D)∈E]≤eϵ​Pr⁡[M−i​(D′)∈E]+δ.Prsubscript𝑀𝑖𝐷𝐸superscript𝑒italic-ϵPrsubscript𝑀𝑖superscript𝐷′𝐸𝛿\displaystyle\Pr[M_{-i}(D)\in E]\leq e^{\epsilon}\Pr[M_{-i}(D^{\prime})\in E]+\delta.

In the setting of model personalization, JDP implies that even if all of users except i𝑖i collude, potentially pooling their private data and local models together, user i𝑖i’s private data are still protected, so long as i𝑖i does not reveal their own model.

4 Main Algorithm and Analysis

Our main algorithm, shown in Algorithm 1, is a personalized version of distributed SGD (Dekel et al., 2012), with a personalization parameter α𝛼\alpha that controls the relative step-size between global and local updates.

At each round t𝑡t, each user i𝑖i samples a fresh datapoint ξi,tsubscript𝜉𝑖𝑡\xi_{i,t} (this could also be a mini-batch), updates its local model θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i}, and sends the gradient with respect to w𝑤w to the central server, which aggregates gradients of all users before updating the global model w𝑤w. The total number of rounds n𝑛n thus corresponds to the number of samples per user. In order to guarantee user-level privacy, we clip each user’s gradients gw,itsuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝑤𝑖𝑡g_{w,i}^{t} before aggregation, and add Gaussian noise, following common practice (Abadi et al., 2016; McMahan et al., 2018; Hu et al., 2021; Chen et al., 2020). The choice of α𝛼\alpha affects the degree by which the algorithm favors local learning over global learning, with α=0𝛼0\alpha=0 forcing local-only updates.

Privacy analysis.

We first establish the formal user-level JDP guarantee of Algorithm 1.

Theorem 4.1 (Privacy).

Suppose we set the noise parameter

σζ≥c​C​n​log⁡(1/δ)N​ϵ,subscript𝜎𝜁𝑐𝐶𝑛1𝛿𝑁italic-ϵ\sigma_{\zeta}\geq c\frac{C\sqrt{n\log(1/\delta)}}{N\epsilon}, (4)

for an absolute constant c𝑐c, then Algorithm 1 satisfies (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-JDP in the billboard model.

We defer the full proof to Appendix B.1. At a high level, the proof first shows that the aggregate information released by the server (the sequence of global model updates) satisfies (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP. Since the sequence of global models are sufficient statistics for each user to identify their personalized model θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i}, the JDP guarantee follows from the billboard lemma (see Lemma B.1).

Generalization analysis.

Our generalization analysis relies on the following assumptions. We begin with an assumption about minimizers of f𝑓f, which relies on the following norm for a vector z=(w,θ1:N)𝑧𝑤subscript𝜃:1𝑁z=(w,{\theta_{1:N}}) that captures the geometry induced by the personalization parameter α𝛼\alpha:

‖z‖α2:=1α​‖w‖2+‖θ1:N‖2.assignsubscriptsuperscriptnorm𝑧2𝛼1𝛼superscriptnorm𝑤2superscriptnormsubscript𝜃:1𝑁2\|z\|^{2}_{\alpha}:=\frac{1}{\alpha}\|w\|^{2}+\|{\theta_{1:N}}\|^{2}. (5)
Assumption 4.2 (Minimizers).

f𝑓f admits a minimizer z∗superscript𝑧z^{*} with finite norm ‖z∗‖αsubscriptnormsuperscript𝑧𝛼\|z^{*}\|_{\alpha}.

In the case of local learning (α=0𝛼0\alpha=0), this implies z∗superscript𝑧z^{*} must have no global component. For joint learning, different minimizers might exist, and our bounds scale with the minimal norm ‖z∗‖αsubscriptnormsuperscript𝑧𝛼\|z^{*}\|_{\alpha} among all such minimizers.

Assumption 4.3 (Convexity and smoothness).

For all i𝑖i and Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i}-almost every ξ𝜉\xi, the function (w,θi)↦fi​(w,θi,ξ)maps-to𝑤subscript𝜃𝑖subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤subscript𝜃𝑖𝜉(w,\theta_{i})\mapsto f_{i}(w,\theta_{i},\xi) is jointly convex and L𝐿L-smooth (its gradients are L𝐿L-Lipschitz).

Note that this implies that f​(z)𝑓𝑧f(z) is jointly convex in z=(w,θ1:N)𝑧𝑤subscript𝜃:1𝑁z=(w,{\theta_{1:N}}). If we consider the example fi​(w,θi,(x,y))=12​(y−(w+θi)⊤​x)2subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤subscript𝜃𝑖𝑥𝑦12superscript𝑦superscript𝑤subscript𝜃𝑖top𝑥2f_{i}(w,\theta_{i},(x,y))=\frac{1}{2}(y-(w+\theta_{i})^{\top}x)^{2}, and assume ‖x‖≤Rnorm𝑥𝑅\|x\|\leq R almost surely, it is easy to verify that the assumption holds with L=2​R2𝐿2superscript𝑅2L=2R^{2}.

We will also make the following boundedness assumption on gradients, which is commonly made in the context of private stochastic optimization (e.g., Bassily et al., 2014; Feldman et al., 2020), and simplifies our analysis by avoiding the need to study the effect of clipping on optimization.

Assumption 4.4 (Bounded gradients).

For all i𝑖i, w𝑤w, θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i}, and Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i}-almost every ξ𝜉\xi, we have ‖∇wfi​(w,θi,ξ)‖≤Gnormsubscript∇𝑤subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤subscript𝜃𝑖𝜉𝐺\|\nabla_{w}f_{i}(w,\theta_{i},\xi)\|\leq G.

This assumptions avoid the need to clip gradients when C≥G𝐶𝐺C\geq G, and our analysis hereafter assumes C=G𝐶𝐺C=G. We note that G𝐺G may be large in some cases, growing with the norm of optimal parameters, thus smaller values of C𝐶C may often be beneficial in practice for better privacy guarantees.

Gradient variances.

We consider the following variance quantities, which we assume to be finite, and which are obtained by considering gradients at a given minimizer z∗superscript𝑧z^{*}:

σw,i2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑤𝑖2\displaystyle\sigma_{w,i}^{2} =𝔼ξ⁡‖∇wfi​(w∗,θi∗,ξ)−∇wfi​(w∗,θi∗)‖2absentsubscript𝔼𝜉superscriptnormsubscript∇𝑤subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝑤superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝜉subscript∇𝑤subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝑤superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖2\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}_{\xi}\|\nabla_{w}f_{i}(w^{*},\theta_{i}^{*},\xi)-\nabla_{w}f_{i}(w^{*},\theta_{i}^{*})\|^{2}
σθ,i2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝜃𝑖2\displaystyle\sigma_{\theta,i}^{2} =𝔼ξ⁡‖∇θfi​(w∗,θi∗,ξ)‖2absentsubscript𝔼𝜉superscriptnormsubscript∇𝜃subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝑤superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝜉2\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}_{\xi}\|\nabla_{\theta}f_{i}(w^{*},\theta_{i}^{*},\xi)\|^{2}
σ¯w2superscriptsubscript¯𝜎𝑤2\displaystyle\bar{\sigma}_{w}^{2} =1N​∑iσw,i2,σ¯θ2=1N​∑iσθ,i2.formulae-sequenceabsent1𝑁subscript𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑤𝑖2superscriptsubscript¯𝜎𝜃21𝑁subscript𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜎𝜃𝑖2\displaystyle=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i}\sigma_{w,i}^{2},\qquad\bar{\sigma}_{\theta}^{2}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i}\sigma_{\theta,i}^{2}.

As an example, note that in a simple additive model (3) with squared loss and additive label noise of variance τ2superscript𝜏2\tau^{2}, we have σw,i2=σθ,i2=τ2​Tr⁡(𝔼Pi⁡[x​x⊤])superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑤𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝜃𝑖2superscript𝜏2Trsubscript𝔼subscript𝑃𝑖𝑥superscript𝑥top\sigma_{w,i}^{2}=\sigma_{\theta,i}^{2}=\tau^{2}\operatorname{Tr}(\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}_{P_{i}}[xx^{\top}]), recovering standard statistical quantities. If the algorithm relies on mini-batches of size m𝑚m instead of single datapoints, we may then replace σw,i2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑤𝑖2\sigma_{w,i}^{2} and σθ,i2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝜃𝑖2\sigma_{\theta,i}^{2} by σw,i2/msuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑤𝑖2𝑚\sigma_{w,i}^{2}/m and σθ,i2/msuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝜃𝑖2𝑚\sigma_{\theta,i}^{2}/m, respectively, by averaging gradients over the mini-batches.

We now provide our main result on the convergence rate of Algorithm 1, which also yields a generalization bound on the excess risk. The proof is in Appendix B.2.

Theorem 4.5 (Generalization).

Under Assumptions 4.2, 4.3, and 4.4, let z∗=(w∗,θ1:N∗)superscript𝑧superscript𝑤superscriptsubscript𝜃:1𝑁z^{*}=(w^{*},{\theta_{1:N}}^{*}) be any minimizer of f𝑓f, Lα:=L​max⁡(α,1N)assignsubscript𝐿𝛼𝐿𝛼1𝑁L_{\alpha}:=L\max(\alpha,\frac{1}{N}), and

σt​o​t,α2:=α​σ¯w2+σ¯θ2N+α​dw​σζ2.assignsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑡𝑜𝑡𝛼2𝛼superscriptsubscript¯𝜎𝑤2superscriptsubscript¯𝜎𝜃2𝑁𝛼subscript𝑑𝑤superscriptsubscript𝜎𝜁2\sigma_{tot,\alpha}^{2}:=\frac{\alpha\bar{\sigma}_{w}^{2}+\bar{\sigma}_{\theta}^{2}}{N}+\alpha d_{w}\sigma_{\zeta}^{2}. (6)

With η=min⁡{14​Lα,‖z∗‖αn​σt​o​t,α}𝜂14subscript𝐿𝛼subscriptnormsuperscript𝑧𝛼𝑛subscript𝜎𝑡𝑜𝑡𝛼\eta=\min\{\frac{1}{4L_{\alpha}},\frac{\|z^{*}\|_{\alpha}}{\sqrt{n}\sigma_{tot,\alpha}}\} and C=G𝐶𝐺C=G, Algorithm 1 satisfies

𝔼[\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[ f(z¯n)−f(z∗)]≤4​Lα​‖z∗‖α2n+3σt​o​t,α​‖z∗‖αn,\displaystyle f(\bar{z}_{n})-f(z^{*})]\leq\frac{4L_{\alpha}\|z^{*}\|_{\alpha}^{2}}{n}+3\frac{\sigma_{tot,\alpha}\|z^{*}\|_{\alpha}}{\sqrt{n}}, (7)

with z¯n=1n​∑t=0n−1ztsubscript¯𝑧𝑛1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑛1subscript𝑧𝑡\bar{z}_{n}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{t=0}^{n-1}z_{t}. In particular, with σζsubscript𝜎𝜁\sigma_{\zeta} as in (4), hiding absolute constants, we have the following generalization bound:

𝔼⁡[f​(z¯n)−f​(z∗)]≲less-than-or-similar-to𝔼𝑓subscript¯𝑧𝑛𝑓superscript𝑧absent\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[f(\bar{z}_{n})-f(z^{*})]\lesssim (8)
Lα​‖z∗‖α2n+‖z∗‖α​α​σ¯w2+σ¯θ2N​n+‖z∗‖α​α​dw​G2​log⁡(1δ)N2​ϵ2subscript𝐿𝛼superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscript𝑧𝛼2𝑛subscriptnormsuperscript𝑧𝛼𝛼superscriptsubscript¯𝜎𝑤2superscriptsubscript¯𝜎𝜃2𝑁𝑛subscriptnormsuperscript𝑧𝛼𝛼subscript𝑑𝑤superscript𝐺21𝛿superscript𝑁2superscriptitalic-ϵ2\displaystyle\frac{L_{\alpha}\|z^{*}\|_{\alpha}^{2}}{n}+\|z^{*}\|_{\alpha}\sqrt{\frac{\alpha\bar{\sigma}_{w}^{2}+\bar{\sigma}_{\theta}^{2}}{Nn}}+\|z^{*}\|_{\alpha}\sqrt{\frac{\alpha{d_{w}}G^{2}\log(\frac{1}{\delta})}{N^{2}\epsilon^{2}}} (9)

The generalization bound takes the form (2), with a cost of privacy that does not depend on the number of samples per user n𝑛n. As is common in the analysis of SGD, our bound displays a bias term that decays as 1/n1𝑛1/n, and a variance term decaying as 1/n1𝑛1/\sqrt{n}, controlled by the gradient variance σt​o​t,α2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑡𝑜𝑡𝛼2\sigma_{tot,\alpha}^{2}. Ignoring the privacy noise, given that we use N𝑁N samples at each round, this variance scales as 1/N1𝑁1/N, leading to an overall asymptotic rate of 1/N​n1𝑁𝑛1/\sqrt{Nn}, where N​n𝑁𝑛Nn is the total sample size. Using minibatches of size m𝑚m would further improve this to 1/N​n​m1𝑁𝑛𝑚1/\sqrt{Nnm}, where the total number of samples is now N​n​m𝑁𝑛𝑚Nnm.

Local vs global learning.

Note that when multiple minimizers z∗superscript𝑧z^{*} exist, one may choose the one with minimal norm ‖z∗‖αsubscriptnormsuperscript𝑧𝛼\|z^{*}\|_{\alpha}. If we consider the additive model (3), we may always consider a minimizer of the form z∗=(0,θ1:N∗)superscript𝑧0subscriptsuperscript𝜃:1𝑁z^{*}=(0,\theta^{*}_{1:N}). Then ‖z∗‖αsubscriptnormsuperscript𝑧𝛼\|z^{*}\|_{\alpha} is bounded even for α=0𝛼0\alpha=0 (local learning), which yields an excess risk of order

L​∑i‖θi∗‖2N​n+σ¯θ2​∑i‖θi∗‖2N​n.𝐿subscript𝑖superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖2𝑁𝑛superscriptsubscript¯𝜎𝜃2subscript𝑖superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖2𝑁𝑛\frac{L\sum_{i}\|\theta_{i}^{*}\|^{2}}{Nn}+\sqrt{\frac{\bar{\sigma}_{\theta}^{2}\sum_{i}\|\theta_{i}^{*}\|^{2}}{Nn}}.

In particular, there is no cost for privacy. If we further assume θi∗=v∗superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖superscript𝑣\theta_{i}^{*}=v^{*} for all i𝑖i, this becomes

L​‖v∗‖2n+‖v∗‖​σ¯θ2n.𝐿superscriptnormsuperscript𝑣2𝑛normsuperscript𝑣superscriptsubscript¯𝜎𝜃2𝑛\frac{L\|v^{*}\|^{2}}{n}+\|v^{*}\|\sqrt{\frac{\bar{\sigma}_{\theta}^{2}}{n}}.

We see slow convergence that does not improve with N𝑁N, which is expected given that no information is shared across users. In this setting, we may instead consider a different minimizer z∗=(v∗,0)superscript𝑧superscript𝑣0z^{*}=(v^{*},0), for which taking the limit α→∞→𝛼\alpha\to\infty (global learning) yields the excess risk of order

L​‖v∗‖2n+‖v∗‖​σ¯w2N​n+‖v∗‖​dw​G2​log⁡(1δ)N2​ϵ2.𝐿superscriptnormsuperscript𝑣2𝑛normsuperscript𝑣superscriptsubscript¯𝜎𝑤2𝑁𝑛normsuperscript𝑣subscript𝑑𝑤superscript𝐺21𝛿superscript𝑁2superscriptitalic-ϵ2\frac{L\|v^{*}\|^{2}}{n}+\|v^{*}\|\sqrt{\frac{\bar{\sigma}_{w}^{2}}{Nn}}+\|v^{*}\|\sqrt{\frac{{d_{w}}G^{2}\log(\frac{1}{\delta})}{N^{2}\epsilon^{2}}}.

The variance term now decays faster for large N𝑁N, but has an additional privacy term, which decreases quickly with N𝑁N but does not improve with large n𝑛n and may be quite large, particularly in high dimensions, consistent with lower bounds for differentially private optimization (Bassily et al., 2014).

Characterizing benefits of personalization.

Depending on the number of samples per user n𝑛n, it may be helpful to choose varying levels of personalization α𝛼\alpha to adjust this tradeoff, from large α𝛼\alpha for small n𝑛n to small α𝛼\alpha for large n𝑛n when the privacy cost dominates the bound. The next lemma quantifies this tradeoff for the additive model with homogeneous users (i.e., θ1∗=⋯=θN∗superscriptsubscript𝜃1⋯superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑁\theta_{1}^{*}=\cdots=\theta_{N}^{*}):

Lemma 4.6 (Threshold on n𝑛n for personalization benefits).

Assume (v,0)𝑣0(v,0) is a minimizer of f𝑓f, with f𝑓f an additive model of the form (3). For any α𝛼\alpha, the minimizer with minimal α𝛼\alpha-norm is given by (w,θ1:N)𝑤subscript𝜃:1𝑁(w,{\theta_{1:N}}) with w=α​Nα​N+1​v𝑤𝛼𝑁𝛼𝑁1𝑣w=\frac{\alpha N}{\alpha N+1}v and θi=1α​N+1​vsubscript𝜃𝑖1𝛼𝑁1𝑣\theta_{i}=\frac{1}{\alpha N+1}v. Assuming σ¯w=σ¯θ=σsubscript¯𝜎𝑤subscript¯𝜎𝜃𝜎\bar{\sigma}_{w}=\bar{\sigma}_{\theta}=\sigma, the variance term in the excess risk (9) with n𝑛n samples per user is monotonic in α𝛼\alpha, taking the form:

‖v‖​Nα​N+1​((α+1)​σ2N​n+α​dw​G2​log⁡(1/δ)N2​ϵ2).norm𝑣𝑁𝛼𝑁1𝛼1superscript𝜎2𝑁𝑛𝛼subscript𝑑𝑤superscript𝐺21𝛿superscript𝑁2superscriptitalic-ϵ2\|v\|\sqrt{\frac{N}{\alpha N+1}\left(\frac{(\alpha+1)\sigma^{2}}{Nn}+\frac{\alpha{d_{w}}G^{2}\log(1/\delta)}{N^{2}\epsilon^{2}}\right)}.

This is non-decreasing with α𝛼\alpha if and only if

n≳N​(N−1)​σ2​ϵ2dw​G2​log⁡(1/δ).greater-than-or-equivalent-to𝑛𝑁𝑁1superscript𝜎2superscriptitalic-ϵ2subscript𝑑𝑤superscript𝐺21𝛿n\gtrsim\frac{N(N-1)\sigma^{2}\epsilon^{2}}{{d_{w}}G^{2}\log(1/\delta)}. (10)

Thus, if we ignore the bias term in (9), this suggests that when (10) holds, using local learning (smaller α𝛼\alpha) should help improve generalization, while if the reverse inequality holds, global learning should be preferred. Eq. (10) suggests that this threshold on the user sample size n𝑛n scales quadratically with the number of users N𝑁N, linearly with the privacy level ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, and inversely with the dimension dwsubscript𝑑𝑤{d_{w}}. When the optimal user parameters are different, this transition would likely happen for smaller n𝑛n, as we expect local models to be useful even at small sample sizes regardless of privacy.

Improving the bias term.

We remark that the bias term decreases as 1/n1𝑛1/n in both local and global learning scenarios described above, and does not improve with the number of users. As in standard SGD (e.g., Dekel et al., 2012), this term decreases with the number of rounds, and may thus decrease more quickly with the number of samples if more communication rounds are performed for the same total number of samples. In Section 5, we show that sampling users at each round can help improve this term.

Comparison to Local SGD.

A common approach for federated optimization is the local SGD (or federated averaging) algorithm (McMahan et al., 2017), which performs multiple local steps before communicating with the server. This is in contrast to our method, which more closely resembles mini-batch SGD. We note that despite its practical success, the known theoretical guarantees of local SGD typically do not improve on mini-batch SGD except for specific settings (Woodworth et al., 2020). Our study therefore focuses on understanding personalization in the SGD setting, but we note that extending our analysis to local SGD is an interesting direction for future work.

5 Heterogeneous Sample Sizes, User Sampling

In this section, we study a variant of Algorithm 1 where we sample some of the users uniformly at each round, with possibly different minibatch sizes for each user. This reflects the fact that users may have different amounts of data, and that not all clients may be available at each round.

Let q𝑞q be the probability of sampling any given user at each round, mi≥1subscript𝑚𝑖1m_{i}\geq 1 be the mini-batch size for user i𝑖i, and define M=∑imi𝑀subscript𝑖subscript𝑚𝑖M=\sum_{i}m_{i} and mmax=maxi⁡misubscript𝑚subscript𝑖subscript𝑚𝑖m_{\max}=\max_{i}m_{i}. Algorithm 2 then optimizes the objective

fm​(w,θ1:N):=∑i=1NmiM​fi​(w,θi).assignsuperscript𝑓𝑚𝑤subscript𝜃:1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑚𝑖𝑀subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤subscript𝜃𝑖f^{m}(w,{\theta_{1:N}}):=\sum_{i=1}^{N}\frac{m_{i}}{M}f_{i}(w,\theta_{i}). (11)

Namely, the algorithm optimizes each user’s performance proportionally to their amount of samples. We denote the number of rounds by T𝑇T here, since it no longer corresponds to the total number of samples per user n𝑛n. Note that the expected total number of samples observed for user i𝑖i after T𝑇T rounds is now given by ni=T​q​misubscript𝑛𝑖𝑇𝑞subscript𝑚𝑖n_{i}=Tqm_{i}.

The following result provides a privacy guarantee for Algorithm 2. Compared to Theorem 4.1, it also leverages a standard argument of privacy amplification by subsampling.

Theorem 5.1 (Privacy with client sampling).

There exist absolute constants c1subscript𝑐1c_{1}, c2subscript𝑐2c_{2} such that for any ϵ<c1​q2​Titalic-ϵsubscript𝑐1superscript𝑞2𝑇\epsilon<c_{1}q^{2}T, if we take

σζ≥c2​C​T​log⁡(1/δ)M​ϵ,subscript𝜎𝜁subscript𝑐2𝐶𝑇1𝛿𝑀italic-ϵ\sigma_{\zeta}\geq c_{2}\frac{C\sqrt{T\log(1/\delta)}}{M\epsilon}, (12)

then Algorithm 2 satisfies (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-JDP.

Note that compared to the uniform sampling case, the clipping parameter C𝐶C may need to be larger since we are clipping the sum of up to mmaxsubscript𝑚m_{\max} gradients. In our generalization analysis hereafter, we thus assume C=G​mmax𝐶𝐺subscript𝑚C=Gm_{\max}, so that clipping is not needed under Assumption 4.4. We now give an optimization and generalization guarantee.

Theorem 5.2 (Generalization with client sampling).

Under Assumptions 4.2, 4.3, and 4.4, let z∗=(w∗,θ1:N∗)superscript𝑧superscript𝑤superscriptsubscript𝜃:1𝑁z^{*}=(w^{*},{\theta_{1:N}}^{*}) be any minimizer of fmsuperscript𝑓𝑚f^{m}, Lm,α=L​max⁡{α+α​mmaxM,mmaxM}subscript𝐿𝑚𝛼𝐿𝛼𝛼subscript𝑚𝑀subscript𝑚𝑀L_{m,\alpha}=L\max\bigl{\{}\alpha+\frac{\alpha m_{\max}}{M},\,\frac{m_{\max}}{M}\bigr{\}}, and

σm,α2:=α​σ¯w,m2+α​σ~w,m2+σ¯θ,m2q​M+α​dw​σζ2,assignsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑚𝛼2𝛼superscriptsubscript¯𝜎𝑤𝑚2𝛼superscriptsubscript~𝜎𝑤𝑚2superscriptsubscript¯𝜎𝜃𝑚2𝑞𝑀𝛼subscript𝑑𝑤superscriptsubscript𝜎𝜁2\sigma_{m,\alpha}^{2}:=\frac{\alpha\bar{\sigma}_{w,m}^{2}+\alpha\tilde{\sigma}_{w,m}^{2}+\bar{\sigma}_{\theta,m}^{2}}{qM}+\alpha d_{w}\sigma_{\zeta}^{2}, (13)

where σ¯w,m2:=1M​∑imi​σw,i2assignsuperscriptsubscript¯𝜎𝑤𝑚21𝑀subscript𝑖subscript𝑚𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑤𝑖2\bar{\sigma}_{w,m}^{2}:=\frac{1}{M}\sum_{i}m_{i}\sigma_{w,i}^{2} and σ¯θ,m2:=1M​∑imi​σθ,i2assignsuperscriptsubscript¯𝜎𝜃𝑚21𝑀subscript𝑖subscript𝑚𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜎𝜃𝑖2\bar{\sigma}_{\theta,m}^{2}:=\frac{1}{M}\sum_{i}m_{i}\sigma_{\theta,i}^{2} and σ~w,m2:=1M​∑iq​(1−q)​mi2​‖∇wfi​(w∗,θi∗)‖2assignsuperscriptsubscript~𝜎𝑤𝑚21𝑀subscript𝑖𝑞1𝑞superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑖2superscriptnormsubscript∇𝑤subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝑤superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖2\tilde{\sigma}_{w,m}^{2}:=\frac{1}{M}\sum_{i}q(1-q)m_{i}^{2}\|\nabla_{w}f_{i}(w^{*},\theta_{i}^{*})\|^{2}.

With η=min⁡{14​Lm,α,‖z∗‖αT​σm,α}𝜂14subscript𝐿𝑚𝛼subscriptnormsuperscript𝑧𝛼𝑇subscript𝜎𝑚𝛼\eta=\min\bigl{\{}\frac{1}{4L_{m,\alpha}},\frac{\|z^{*}\|_{\alpha}}{\sqrt{T}\sigma_{m,\alpha}}\bigr{\}} and C=Gm:=G​mmax𝐶subscript𝐺𝑚assign𝐺subscript𝑚C=G_{m}:=Gm_{\max}, Algorithm 2 satisfies

𝔼[\displaystyle\!\!\!\!\!\!\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[ fm(z¯T)−fm(z∗)]≤4​Lm,α​‖z∗‖α2T+3σm,α​‖z∗‖αT,\displaystyle f^{m}(\bar{z}_{T})-f^{m}(z^{*})]\leq\frac{4L_{m,\alpha}\|z^{*}\|_{\alpha}^{2}}{T}+3\frac{\sigma_{m,\alpha}\|z^{*}\|_{\alpha}}{\sqrt{T}},\!\!\!\!\!\!

with z¯T=1T​∑t=0T−1ztsubscript¯𝑧𝑇1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1subscript𝑧𝑡\bar{z}_{T}=\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}z_{t}. Taking σζsubscript𝜎𝜁\sigma_{\zeta} as in (12), we have:

𝔼⁡[fm​(z¯T)−fm​(z∗)]≲Lm,α​‖z∗‖α2T+less-than-or-similar-to𝔼superscript𝑓𝑚subscript¯𝑧𝑇superscript𝑓𝑚superscript𝑧limit-fromsubscript𝐿𝑚𝛼superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscript𝑧𝛼2𝑇\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[f^{m}(\bar{z}_{T})-f^{m}(z^{*})]\lesssim\frac{L_{m,\alpha}\|z^{*}\|_{\alpha}^{2}}{T}+ (14)
+‖z∗‖α​α​σ¯w,m2+α​σ~w,m2+σ¯θ,m2q​M​T+α​dw​Gm2​log⁡(1δ)M2​ϵ2subscriptnormsuperscript𝑧𝛼𝛼superscriptsubscript¯𝜎𝑤𝑚2𝛼superscriptsubscript~𝜎𝑤𝑚2superscriptsubscript¯𝜎𝜃𝑚2𝑞𝑀𝑇𝛼subscript𝑑𝑤superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑚21𝛿superscript𝑀2superscriptitalic-ϵ2\displaystyle+\|z^{*}\|_{\alpha}\sqrt{\frac{\alpha\bar{\sigma}_{w,m}^{2}\!+\!\alpha\tilde{\sigma}_{w,m}^{2}+\bar{\sigma}_{\theta,m}^{2}}{qMT}\!+\!\frac{\alpha{d_{w}}G_{m}^{2}\log(\frac{1}{\delta})}{M^{2}\epsilon^{2}}}

Note that the privacy cost now scales with Gm/M=G​mmax/Msubscript𝐺𝑚𝑀𝐺subscript𝑚𝑀G_{m}/M=Gm_{\max}/M instead of G/N𝐺𝑁G/N in Theorem 4.5. Note that we have G​mmax/M≥G/N𝐺subscript𝑚𝑀𝐺𝑁Gm_{\max}/M\geq G/N, with equality if and only if all the misubscript𝑚𝑖m_{i} are equal. This highlights the additional cost of privacy with heterogeneous sample sizes, particularly when some users have much more data than others. Compared to Theorem 4.5, there is also an additional variance term σ~w,msubscript~𝜎𝑤𝑚\tilde{\sigma}_{w,m} induced by the randomness of client sampling. Note that σ~w,msubscript~𝜎𝑤𝑚\tilde{\sigma}_{w,m} vanishes when (i) q=1𝑞1q=1 (i.e., no sampling), or (ii) ∇wfi​(w∗,θi∗)=0subscript∇𝑤subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝑤superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖0\nabla_{w}f_{i}(w^{*},\theta_{i}^{*})=0 for all i𝑖i, which always holds for the additive model (3).

When all users are sampled (q=1𝑞1q=1) and mi=1subscript𝑚𝑖1m_{i}=1 for each user, we have M=N𝑀𝑁M=N and σ~w,m=0subscript~𝜎𝑤𝑚0\tilde{\sigma}_{w,m}=0, and we recover the same bound as in Theorem 4.5, where T=n𝑇𝑛T=n corresponds to the number of samples per user. In this case the bias term decreases slowly as 1/n1𝑛1/n. In contrast, if mi=1subscript𝑚𝑖1m_{i}=1 and q=1/N𝑞1𝑁q=1/N, i.e., we sample one user per round on average, then q​M=1𝑞𝑀1qM=1, and T𝑇T now corresponds to the total number of samples N​n𝑁𝑛Nn. The bias term now decreases as 1/N​n1𝑁𝑛1/Nn, while the variance decreases at the same 1/N​n1𝑁𝑛1/\sqrt{Nn} rate. Of course, this comes at the cost of more frequent communication rounds, since each round only uses the data of a single user.

Optimizing average user performance.

In some cases, we may have clients with heterogeneous amounts of data, but still want to optimize the average performance f𝑓f in (1), rather than the weighted average fmsuperscript𝑓𝑚f^{m} in (11). This can be achieved by replacing gθ,itsuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝜃𝑖𝑡g_{\theta,i}^{t} and gw,itsuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝑤𝑖𝑡g_{w,i}^{t} by averages over the minibatch instead of sums in Algorithm 2. This leads to the following guarantee on the excess risk (see Appendix B.6):

𝔼⁡[f​(z¯T)−f​(z∗)]≲less-than-or-similar-to𝔼𝑓subscript¯𝑧𝑇𝑓superscript𝑧absent\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[f(\bar{z}_{T})-f(z^{*})]\lesssim (15)
Lα​‖z∗‖α2T+‖z∗‖α​α​σ¯w2+σ¯θ2q​N​mmin​T+α​dw​G2​log⁡(1δ)N2​ϵ2.subscript𝐿𝛼superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscript𝑧𝛼2𝑇subscriptnormsuperscript𝑧𝛼𝛼superscriptsubscript¯𝜎𝑤2superscriptsubscript¯𝜎𝜃2𝑞𝑁subscript𝑚𝑇𝛼subscript𝑑𝑤superscript𝐺21𝛿superscript𝑁2superscriptitalic-ϵ2\displaystyle\frac{L_{\alpha}\|z^{*}\|_{\alpha}^{2}}{T}+\|z^{*}\|_{\alpha}\sqrt{\frac{\alpha\bar{\sigma}_{w}^{2}+\bar{\sigma}_{\theta}^{2}}{qNm_{\min}T}+\frac{\alpha{d_{w}}G^{2}\log(\frac{1}{\delta})}{N^{2}\epsilon^{2}}}. (16)

Note that the privacy cost is similar to the case with homogeneous data in Section 4, rather than the larger cost of Theorem 5.2, since we are now treating each user equally. Nevertheless, the variance term displays an effective total sample size of ntot=q​N​mmin​Tsubscript𝑛tot𝑞𝑁subscript𝑚𝑇n_{\text{tot}}=qNm_{\min}T, which is smaller than in Theorem 5.2, where ntot=q​M​Tsubscript𝑛tot𝑞𝑀𝑇n_{\text{tot}}=qMT corresponds to the expected total number of samples, unless all the misubscript𝑚𝑖m_{i} are equal. This highlights that this improvement in privacy comes at a cost in statistical efficiency.

6 Experiments

In this section, we present numerical experiments that illustrate our theoretical guarantees on both synthetic and real-world federated learning datasets. Our code is available at https://github.com/albietz/ppsgd.

Experiment setup.

We consider linear additive models of the form (3) with the squared loss. For classification datasets, we use a one-versus-all setup. Unless otherwise mentioned, we run our algorithms for one pass over the data, simulating the online setting considered by our theory. We sample a fixed number of users (denoted Q𝑄Q) at each iteration, chosen randomly without replacement, and consider minibatches of size m=10𝑚10m=10 for each user. Following standard practice, we compute privacy guarantees ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon at each iteration using the moments accountant (Abadi et al., 2016), with a fixed δ=10−4𝛿superscript104\delta=10^{-4}, after applying Gaussian noise of variance σζ2=σ2​C2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝜁2superscript𝜎2superscript𝐶2\sigma_{\zeta}^{2}=\sigma^{2}C^{2}, where C𝐶C is a clipping parameter and σ𝜎\sigma a noise multiplier. For each run, we consider a fixed step-size η𝜂\eta, personalization parameter α𝛼\alpha, clipping parameter C𝐶C, and noise multiplier σ𝜎\sigma, chosen from a grid (see Appendix A). In order to assess the best achievable performance, we optimize the learning rate separately at each number of iterations reported in our figures.

Synthetic dataset.

We begin with a synthetic regression example, where each user’s data is generated from a ground truth linear model, and multiple coordinates of the parameters are shared across users. We consider N=1000𝑁1000N=1000 users and data in d=100𝑑100d=100 dimensions. The parameters θi∗superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i}^{*} are generated as follows from a random θ0∼𝒩​(0,102​Id)similar-tosubscript𝜃0𝒩0superscript102subscript𝐼𝑑\theta_{0}\sim{\mathcal{N}}(0,10^{2}I_{d}):

[θi∗]1:95subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑖:195\displaystyle[\theta^{*}_{i}]_{1:95} =[θ0]1:95absentsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝜃0:195\displaystyle=[\theta_{0}]_{1:95}
[θi∗]96:100subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑖:96100\displaystyle[\theta^{*}_{i}]_{96:100} =[θ0]96:100+δi,δi∼𝒩​(0,0.012​I),formulae-sequenceabsentsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝜃0:96100subscript𝛿𝑖similar-tosubscript𝛿𝑖𝒩0superscript0.012𝐼\displaystyle=[\theta_{0}]_{96:100}+\delta_{i},\quad\delta_{i}\sim{\mathcal{N}}(0,0.01^{2}I),

while the samples (xi,yi)subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖(x_{i},y_{i}) for user i𝑖i are generated by the following process:

xisubscript𝑥𝑖\displaystyle x_{i} ∼𝒩(0,Σ),Σ=diag{λk}k=1d,λk=1/k\displaystyle\sim{\mathcal{N}}(0,\Sigma),\qquad\Sigma=\operatorname{diag}\{\lambda_{k}\}_{k=1}^{d},\lambda_{k}=1/k
yisubscript𝑦𝑖\displaystyle y_{i} =θi∗⊤​xi+εi,εi∼𝒩​(0,τ2).formulae-sequenceabsentsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖absenttopsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝜀𝑖similar-tosubscript𝜀𝑖𝒩0superscript𝜏2\displaystyle=\theta_{i}^{*\top}x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i},\quad\varepsilon_{i}\sim{\mathcal{N}}(0,\tau^{2}).

With this setup, the excess risk can be computed in closed form, and is given by 1N​∑i‖w+θi−θi∗‖Σ21𝑁subscript𝑖superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑤subscript𝜃𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖Σ2\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i}\|w+\theta_{i}-\theta_{i}^{*}\|_{\Sigma}^{2}, and is shown in Figure 1a. We observe that global learning (α=∞𝛼\alpha=\infty) enjoys faster convergence at initial iterations in all cases, thanks to better data efficiency, but eventually stops improving, even without privacy noise, since minimizing risk requires personalization in this model. Small choices of α𝛼\alpha lead to better performance in later iterations, and with larger levels of privacy noise, full local learning (α=0𝛼0\alpha=0) dominates joint learning quite early in the learning process, after about 200 iterations, i.e., 2000 samples per user.

Stackoverflow tag prediction.

We now consider a subset of the Stackoverflow dataset111https://www.tensorflow.org/federated/api_docs/python/tff/simulation/datasets/stackoverflow/load_data consisting of N=500𝑁500N=500 users, each with about 300–500 training and 10–100 test documents in a bag-of-words format of dimension 5000. The task is to predict Stackoverflow tags from documents that consist of user questions, and we use the 80 most popular tags as labels.

In Figure 1b, we show the top-1 accuracy on the test set, while running our method for a single pass over the data, sampling Q=10𝑄10Q=10 users and m=10𝑚10m=10 documents per user at each iteration. We observe that without privacy, the best performance is obtained with an intermediate amount of personalization, α=10𝛼10\alpha=10, suggesting that local models are helpful for generalization on this dataset. With privacy noise, however, models with large α𝛼\alpha quickly degrade in performance, and small α𝛼\alpha performs best for achieving reasonable privacy levels. Overall, personalization plays a key role for improving the privacy–accuracy tradeoff on this dataset, as shown in Figure 2.

Federated EMNIST.

Finally, we consider a subset of the federated EMNIST digit classification dataset222https://www.tensorflow.org/federated/api_docs/python/tff/simulation/datasets/emnist/load_data consisting of N=1000𝑁1000N=1000 users with about 100100100 training and 101010 test samples per user. Here, a single pass does not lead to good performance, suggesting this may be a hard learning problem that benefits from multiple passes (Pillaud-Vivien et al., 2018). We thus run our method for 20 epochs, sampling 10 users and 10 images per user at each iteration, and show the resulting test accuracy in Figure 1c. On this dataset, we see that local learning does generally poorly, perhaps because there is a lot of shared structure in images across users that benefits significantly from global learning. Nevertheless, there is still a benefit to using small α𝛼\alpha for achieving good privacy guarantees, and personalization still plays a role in improving the privacy–accuracy tradeoff (albeit less pronounced than on Stackoverflow, see Figure 2).

In Figure 1d, we show similar plots on federated EMNIST for a 4-layer CNN with a shared global representation ΦW​(x)subscriptΦ𝑊𝑥\Phi_{W}(x) and an additive model at the output layer, leading to a loss of the form

fi​((w,W),θi,(x,y))=ℓ​(y,(w+θi)⊤​ΦW​(x)).subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤𝑊subscript𝜃𝑖𝑥𝑦ℓ𝑦superscript𝑤subscript𝜃𝑖topsubscriptΦ𝑊𝑥f_{i}((w,W),\theta_{i},(x,y))=\ell(y,(w+\theta_{i})^{\top}\Phi_{W}(x)).

We see that similar conclusions hold in this non-convex scenario, namely, small α𝛼\alpha is helpful for achieving better privacy guarantees, while large α𝛼\alpha leads to better accuracy for poor privacy levels. Here the local-only models (α=0𝛼0\alpha=0) perform very poorly, since the global representation has frozen random weights, highlighting that learning a useful representation in this model requires a privacy cost.

7 Discussion and Conclusion

In this paper, we studied personalized private federated optimization algorithms, providing generalization guarantees in the convex setting that highlight the role of personalization and privacy. We show both theoretically and empirically that adjusting the amount of personalization is always beneficial for improving the accuracy–privacy tradeoff, by providing a way to attenuate the cost of privacy through local learning at large sample sizes. Promising future directions include extending our analysis to different models of personalization, e.g., based on neural networks, and to provide adaptive algorithms which may dynamically adjust the level of personalization in an online fashion.

Appendix B Proofs of Main Results

For proving the privacy guarantees, we make use of the following billboard lemma.

Lemma B.1 (Billboard Lemma, Hsu et al., 2014).

Suppose a message broadcasting mechanism ℳ:𝒟→𝒲:ℳ→𝒟𝒲\mathcal{M}:\mathcal{D}\rightarrow\mathcal{W} is (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-differentially private. Consider any set of functions: gi:𝒟i×𝒲→𝒲′:subscript𝑔𝑖→subscript𝒟𝑖𝒲superscript𝒲′g_{i}:\mathcal{D}_{i}\times\mathcal{W}\rightarrow\mathcal{W}^{\prime}. The composition {gi​(Πi​𝒟,ℳ​(𝒟))}subscript𝑔𝑖subscriptΠ𝑖𝒟ℳ𝒟\{g_{i}(\Pi_{i}\mathcal{D},\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}))\} is (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-joint differentially private, where Πi:𝒟→𝒟i:subscriptΠ𝑖→𝒟subscript𝒟𝑖\Pi_{i}:\mathcal{D}\rightarrow\mathcal{D}_{i} is the projection of 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} onto 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}.

B.1 Proof of Theorem 4.1 (Privacy for PP-SGD)

Proof.

To prove the JDP guarantee, by the billboard lemma (Lemma B.1), it is sufficient to show that the global model updates satisfy standard DP w.r.t. any changes to a single user’s data.

With the assumption that gradients are uniformly bounded by G𝐺G, each update of the global models has ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} sensitivity bounded by α​η/N𝛼𝜂𝑁\alpha\eta/N w.r.t. any change to a single user’s data. If we take

σζ≥c​G​n​log⁡(1/δ)N​ϵ,subscript𝜎𝜁𝑐𝐺𝑛1𝛿𝑁italic-ϵ\sigma_{\zeta}\geq c\frac{G\sqrt{n\log(1/\delta)}}{N\epsilon},

for some absolute constant c𝑐c, then by the Gaussian mechanism, each update is (ϵn​log⁡(1/δ),δ)italic-ϵ𝑛1𝛿𝛿(\frac{\epsilon}{\sqrt{n\log(1/\delta)}},\delta)-differentially private, and by the advanced composition theorem (Dwork et al., 2010b), the algorithm that outputs global models is (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-differentially private after n𝑛n steps.

When considering both local and global models as outputs of the algorithm, combining the above with the billboard lemma yields the desired JDP guarantee.

∎

B.2 Proof of Theorem 4.5 (Generalization for PP-SGD)

Proof.

Note that the algorithm updates be written jointly on zt=(wt,θt)subscript𝑧𝑡subscript𝑤𝑡subscript𝜃𝑡z_{t}=(w_{t},\theta_{t}) as

ztsubscript𝑧𝑡\displaystyle z_{t} =zt−1−η​H−1​gt,absentsubscript𝑧𝑡1𝜂superscript𝐻1subscript𝑔𝑡\displaystyle=z_{t-1}-\eta H^{-1}g_{t}, (17)
with ​gtwith subscript𝑔𝑡\displaystyle\text{with }g_{t} =(1N​∑i=1N∇wfi​(wt−1,θi,t−1,ξi,t)+ζt1N​∇θf1​(wt−1,θ1,t−1,ξ1,t)⋮1N​∇θfN​(wt−1,θN,t−1,ξN,t)),absentmatrix1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript∇𝑤subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑤𝑡1subscript𝜃𝑖𝑡1subscript𝜉𝑖𝑡subscript𝜁𝑡1𝑁subscript∇𝜃subscript𝑓1subscript𝑤𝑡1subscript𝜃1𝑡1subscript𝜉1𝑡⋮1𝑁subscript∇𝜃subscript𝑓𝑁subscript𝑤𝑡1subscript𝜃𝑁𝑡1subscript𝜉𝑁𝑡\displaystyle=\left(\begin{matrix}\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\nabla_{w}f_{i}(w_{t-1},\theta_{i,t-1},\xi_{i,t})+\zeta_{t}\\ \frac{1}{N}\nabla_{\theta}f_{1}(w_{t-1},\theta_{1,t-1},\xi_{1,t})\\ \vdots\\ \frac{1}{N}\nabla_{\theta}f_{N}(w_{t-1},\theta_{N,t-1},\xi_{N,t})\end{matrix}\right), (18)

where H𝐻H is a pre-conditioner of the form

B.3 Proof of Lemma 4.6 (effect of α𝛼\alpha and critical sample size)

Proof.

We would like to make (w+θi)⊤​x=v⊤​xsuperscript𝑤subscript𝜃𝑖top𝑥superscript𝑣top𝑥(w+\theta_{i})^{\top}x=v^{\top}x for all x𝑥x, while minimizing ‖(w,θ1:N)‖αsubscriptnorm𝑤subscript𝜃:1𝑁𝛼\|(w,\theta_{1:N})\|_{\alpha}. This is achieved by solving the following minimization problem:

minw,θ1:Nsubscript𝑤subscript𝜃:1𝑁\displaystyle\min_{w,\theta_{1:N}}\quad 1α​‖w‖2+∑i‖θi‖21𝛼superscriptnorm𝑤2subscript𝑖superscriptnormsubscript𝜃𝑖2\displaystyle\frac{1}{\alpha}\|w\|^{2}+\sum_{i}\|\theta_{i}\|^{2}
s.t.formulae-sequence𝑠𝑡\displaystyle s.t.\quad w+θi=v𝑤subscript𝜃𝑖𝑣\displaystyle w+\theta_{i}=v

To solve w𝑤w, we minimize 1α​‖w‖2+∑i‖v−w‖2=1α​‖w‖2+N​‖v−w‖21𝛼superscriptnorm𝑤2subscript𝑖superscriptnorm𝑣𝑤21𝛼superscriptnorm𝑤2𝑁superscriptnorm𝑣𝑤2\frac{1}{\alpha}\|w\|^{2}+\sum_{i}\|v-w\|^{2}=\frac{1}{\alpha}\|w\|^{2}+N\|v-w\|^{2}, which gives w=α​Nα​N+1​v𝑤𝛼𝑁𝛼𝑁1𝑣w=\frac{\alpha N}{\alpha N+1}v and thus θi=1α​N+1​vsubscript𝜃𝑖1𝛼𝑁1𝑣\theta_{i}=\frac{1}{\alpha N+1}v for all i𝑖i.

Therefore,

‖z∗‖α=1α​(α​Nα​N+1)2​‖v‖2+N​(1α​N+1)2​‖v‖2=Nα​N+1​‖v‖.subscriptnormsuperscript𝑧𝛼1𝛼superscript𝛼𝑁𝛼𝑁12superscriptnorm𝑣2𝑁superscript1𝛼𝑁12superscriptnorm𝑣2𝑁𝛼𝑁1norm𝑣\displaystyle\|z^{*}\|_{\alpha}=\sqrt{\frac{1}{\alpha}\left(\frac{\alpha N}{\alpha N+1}\right)^{2}\|v\|^{2}+N\left(\frac{1}{\alpha N+1}\right)^{2}\|v\|^{2}}=\sqrt{\frac{N}{\alpha N+1}}\|v\|.

Plugging this into (9), we see that the variance term takes the form specified in the lemma statement.

To see the effect of α𝛼\alpha to the variance term, we identify the condition for α𝛼\alpha, such that the following function is increasing in α𝛼\alpha:

ψ​(α)=a​(α+1)α​N+1+b​αα​N+1𝜓𝛼𝑎𝛼1𝛼𝑁1𝑏𝛼𝛼𝑁1\displaystyle\psi(\alpha)=\frac{a(\alpha+1)}{\alpha N+1}+\frac{b\alpha}{\alpha N+1}

for constants a,b𝑎𝑏a,b. Its derivative can be calculated as follows:

ψ′​(α)=a​(α​N+1)−a​(α+1)​N+b​(α​N+1)−b​α​N(α​N+1)2=a​(1−N)+b(α​N+1)2.superscript𝜓′𝛼𝑎𝛼𝑁1𝑎𝛼1𝑁𝑏𝛼𝑁1𝑏𝛼𝑁superscript𝛼𝑁12𝑎1𝑁𝑏superscript𝛼𝑁12\displaystyle\psi^{\prime}(\alpha)=\frac{a(\alpha N+1)-a(\alpha+1)N+b(\alpha N+1)-b\alpha N}{(\alpha N+1)^{2}}=\frac{a(1-N)+b}{(\alpha N+1)^{2}}.

Thus, ψ​(α)𝜓𝛼\psi(\alpha) is increasing in α𝛼\alpha if and only if a​(N−1)≤b𝑎𝑁1𝑏a(N-1)\leq b. In our case, a=σ2n𝑎superscript𝜎2𝑛a=\frac{\sigma^{2}}{n} and b=c​dw​G2​log⁡(1/δ)N​ϵ𝑏𝑐subscript𝑑𝑤superscript𝐺21𝛿𝑁italic-ϵb=c\frac{d_{w}G^{2}\log(1/\delta)}{N\epsilon}, and the condition a​(N−1)≤b𝑎𝑁1𝑏a(N-1)\leq b is equivalent to

n≥(N2−N)​σ2​ϵc​dw​G2​log⁡(1/δ).𝑛superscript𝑁2𝑁superscript𝜎2italic-ϵ𝑐subscript𝑑𝑤superscript𝐺21𝛿\displaystyle n\geq\frac{(N^{2}-N)\sigma^{2}\epsilon}{cd_{w}G^{2}\log(1/\delta)}.

∎

B.4 Proof of Theorem 5.1 (privacy of PPSGD with client sampling)

Proof.

The proof follows the same lines as that of Proposition 4.1, but additionally leverages a standard argument of privacy amplification by subsampling to accomodate user sampling. Specifically, we use (Abadi et al., 2016, Theorem 1), which leverages Rényi differential privacy to provide an improved dependency on δ𝛿\delta compared to the advanced composition theorem (Dwork et al., 2010b).

In order to apply (Abadi et al., 2016, Theorem 1), we rewrite the global updates as

wt=wt−1−α​ηq​M​(∑i:bi,t=1g~w,it+q​M​ζt).subscript𝑤𝑡subscript𝑤𝑡1𝛼𝜂𝑞𝑀subscript:𝑖subscript𝑏𝑖𝑡1superscriptsubscript~𝑔𝑤𝑖𝑡𝑞𝑀subscript𝜁𝑡w_{t}=w_{t-1}-\frac{\alpha\eta}{qM}\left(\sum_{i:b_{i,t}=1}\tilde{g}_{w,i}^{t}+qM\zeta_{t}\right).

This matches the form of the the updates in (Abadi et al., 2016), with total noise standard deviation q​M​σζ𝑞𝑀subscript𝜎𝜁qM\sigma_{\zeta}, which should equal σ​C𝜎𝐶\sigma C in their notations. Then, by Abadi et al. (2016, Theorem 1), their condition on σ𝜎\sigma becomes:

σζ​q​MC≥c2​q​T​log⁡(1/δ)ϵ.subscript𝜎𝜁𝑞𝑀𝐶subscript𝑐2𝑞𝑇1𝛿italic-ϵ\frac{\sigma_{\zeta}qM}{C}\geq c_{2}\frac{q\sqrt{T\log(1/\delta)}}{\epsilon}.

This guarantees that the global update mechanism after T𝑇T iterations is (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP. This corresponds to the condition in the statement. Combining this with the billboard lemma (Lemma B.1) yields the desired JDP guarantee on the full algorithm output.

∎

Lemma B.3.

B.6 Optimizing average user risk with heterogeneous sample sizes

𝔼⁡[f​(z¯T)−f​(z∗)]≲Lα​‖z∗‖α2T+‖z∗‖α​α​σ¯w,m2+α​σ~w,m2+σ¯θ,m2q​N​T+α​dw​G2​log⁡(1δ)N2​ϵ2.less-than-or-similar-to𝔼𝑓subscript¯𝑧𝑇𝑓superscript𝑧subscript𝐿𝛼superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscript𝑧𝛼2𝑇subscriptnormsuperscript𝑧𝛼𝛼superscriptsubscript¯𝜎𝑤𝑚2𝛼superscriptsubscript~𝜎𝑤𝑚2superscriptsubscript¯𝜎𝜃𝑚2𝑞𝑁𝑇𝛼subscript𝑑𝑤superscript𝐺21𝛿superscript𝑁2superscriptitalic-ϵ2\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[f(\bar{z}_{T})-f(z^{*})]\lesssim\frac{L_{\alpha}\|z^{*}\|_{\alpha}^{2}}{T}+\|z^{*}\|_{\alpha}\sqrt{\frac{\alpha\bar{\sigma}_{w,m}^{2}+\alpha\tilde{\sigma}_{w,m}^{2}+\bar{\sigma}_{\theta,m}^{2}}{qNT}\!+\!\frac{\alpha{d_{w}}G^{2}\log(\frac{1}{\delta})}{N^{2}\epsilon^{2}}}. Proof.
